https://prez.dev/description.@value: The primary purpose for which a borehole was drilled or any secondary purpose that the borehole may acquire during its lifecycle. The vocabulary focuses on drilling purposes within the resources industry, with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. Some terms covered by jurisdictional legislation are highlighted in the provenance field. Variations in terminology within definitions (i.e. usage of borehole, well and wellbore) stem from usage in different sectors of the resources industry, but for the purpose of this vocabulary are considered to be equivalent. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium).

A borehole drilled and cased to enable the removal of groundwater from a mine. Mine dewatering is critical when a mine extends below the water table and groundwater does, due to gravity, infiltrate the mine workings.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Hydrogeology drilling in mining operations is conducted in order to monitor and sample the water table at and around a mining site, retrieve water for use (e.g. for dust control), or to remove water from a mine (dewatering).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Hydrogeology drilling in mining operations is conducted in order to monitor and sample the water table at and around a mining site, retrieve water for use (e.g. for dust control), or to remove water from a mine (dewatering).
A borehole drilled for the purpose of pumping water into an aquifer for disposal at some distance from a mine as a means of dewatering.

A monitoring bore drilled to identify the condition of the groundwater and of the water table at and around a mining site or part thereof (e.g. around open pits, tailings dams and waste dumps). Holes are drilled at intervals and cased with slotted casing, allowing groundwater entry and thus regular checking and sample collection/analysis to determine any variations in the height of the water table, water pressure, water quality, presence of contaminants and salinity.
A well drilled to extract water from an aquifer for use in exploration and/or mining operations, e.g. to supply water for dust control.
